So, in a way, fog formation is acting as a sink by the process of scavenging and as a source by producing secondary aerosol particles, such as ammonium and calcium ion present fog, besides efficiently neutralising acidic aerosols (Sawlani et al. 2019), they lead to the production of new secondary aerosols (Nath and Yadav 2018). Apart from the generation of PAN, ozone and other secondary aerosols amid fog and haze episodes, metals often get bound to PM2.5, increasing the probability of health risks due to inhalation of these airborne metals (Li et al. 2017). The lowered inversion boundary layer that is conducive for the occurrence of fog is also responsible for trapping air pollutants, showing a comparatively higher concentration of pollutants during foggy days, including gases, fine and ultrafine particulate matter (Gupta and Elumalai 2018; Özdemir et al. 2018; Sehgal et al. 2016; Zhang et al. 2015a, b) and consecutively providing more CCN, thus may form a positive feedback loop. The frequency of stratosphere-troposphere Exchange, which acts as a regulator for tropospheric ozone budget, increases during the winter months in India (Ganguly and Tzanis 2011), which may further exacerbate the probability of photochemical smog. These days, it is rare to find clean fog in cities; the fog in cities is usually found to coexist with haze and is loosely referred to as haze-fog (Guo et al. 2020; Fu and Chen 2017; Zhang et al. 2015b).

sec.title: Policies and measures to improve air quality
sec.p: Atmospheric conditions required for fog formation are also suitable for restricting the dispersal of air pollutants, and its ample supply in the locality provides for a more significant number of condensation surfaces for fog droplet formation. Thus, it becomes crucial to reduce air pollution levels. Only policies of China and India are discussed here because the air quality of its many cities is amongst the world’s worst. Moreover, also because China has been able to improve its air quality relatively within a short period of time. Lessons on how to tackle the problem of air pollution? And where the measures are lacking? It can be taken from these two nations.

China’s: China’s enormously growing economy, industries, and urbanization are to be blamed for its current dire air quality (Hernandez 2015; Zheng et al. 2015; Chan and Yao 2008). The air pollution levels in many cities of China were too high in the past decades (Wang 2020; Zheng et al. 2016). However, China has shown remarkable progress in reducing its pollution. China's first law concerning air pollution, the Prevention and Control of Atmospheric Pollution, was enacted in 1987 and was amended in 1995, 2000, 2015, and more recently in 2016 (Fu and Chen 2017). The Law on the Prevention and Control of Atmospheric Pollution is the primary law that provides the framework of all matters concerning air quality and its related affairs. Other laws concerning air quality are- Environmental Impact Assessment Law (2003), Energy Conservation Law (2007), Law on Promoting Clean Production (2012), and Environment Protection Law (2015) (Hernandez 2015). Ambient Air Quality Standards, GB 3095-2012 has laid down limits for SO2, NO2, PM2.5, PM10, O3, and CO in two types of areas, one comprises of natural reserves and scenic areas (Class I); and the other comprises of residential, rural, industrial and mixed-up areas (Class II) (https://www.loc.gov/item/global-legalmonitor/2018-08-16/china-2020-air-pollution-action-plan-released/). Initially, the five-year plans were based on a top-down model, where the standards set at the centre were gradually implemented at different stages of governance as per the hierarchical government structure, in combination with the account as the promotion of the people involved was dependent on the policy implementation (Wang 2020).

Before 2018, air pollution and control-related affairs were dealt with by the Ministry of Environmental Protection (MEP). The climate change, GHG emissions, and energy sector were the responsibility of the National Development and Reform Commission (NDRC). After April 2018 all the responsibilities of the MEP and NDRC were passed on to the Ministry of Ecology and Environment (Regulation of Air Pollution: China). Air Pollution Prevention and Control Action Plan (APPCAP), issued in 2013, was a five-year program aimed to improve the nation’s overall air quality, specifically targeting the regions of Pearl River delta, Yangtze River delta, and Beijing-Tianjin-Hebei. The APPCAP consisted of ten tasks, covering: (1) emission reduction; (2) industrial structure optimisation; (3) acceleration of technological innovation; (4) clean energy supply (5) strict standards for industries; (6) environmental, economic policies; (7) Management and Regulation system; (8) Integrated Regional approach for environmental management; (9) Pollution Monitoring and warning system, and (10) Government, enterprise and societal roles and responsibilities (China Clean air Updates, State Council Air Pollution and Control Action Plan, 2013) called the “Atmospheric Pollution Prevention and Control of the Ten Measures of China” (Fu and Chen 2017). The World Bank provided financial aid under the Program for Results scheme to implement the plans and measures laid down in the APPCAP and the 13th five-year plan (2016–2020) for energy efficiency, renewable energy, and pollution control. With the financial help, waste energy from thermal power plants that was previously released into the atmosphere is now reused in keeping the homes warm in winters, due to which many coal burning boilers were shut down; similarly, the excess heat generated in other manufacturing industries is also redistributing its heat in the local homes alongside providing energy to other small scale industries (Helping China Fight Air Pollution 2018).

The government provided financial aid by introducing the Green Finance Centre (China: Fighting Air Pollution and Climate Change through Clean Energy Financing 2021) to adapt green technology in industries. To further reduce air pollution, the government reduced fossil fuel consumption and replaced non-renewable energy sources with renewable energy resources, greater involvement of social and market factors, and decentralization of policies (Wang 2020). Environment Protection tax was imposed on the industries that were directly releasing pollutants into the environment. The past two decades saw a surge in car purchases; aside from adding to the traffic problem, it also was adding to the already high emissions, so many local governments issued vehicle purchase restriction policies. The restriction policy was able to reduce PM10 levels (He and Jiang 2021). Half of the buses running on the Beijing roads have been electric since 2016, and more than 200,000 e-vehicles in the nation’s capital (He et al. 2019). APPCAP was succeeded by the “Three-year Action plan to Win the Blue Sky Defense War” (2018–2020), whose focus was to bring down the levels of PM2.5 at par with the goals set in the previous plan for the cities which were not able to reach their targets in the previous plan utilizing structural adjustments in industries, energy, transportation, and land (Jiang et al. 2021). Evidence of the improvement made in the air quality was observed in many areas (Cui et al. 2020; Yu et al. 2019; Huang et al. 2018; Chen et al. 2017). In a decade (2010–2019) China decreased its outdoor PM2.5 levels by 30% by the emission curbing actions as a result of proper implementation of APPCAP and its successor measures (State of Global Air 2020). Though China has been able to significantly curtail the emissions of CO, SO2, PM10, PM2.5 but O3 was observed to be increasing, actions are still needed to bring the emissions further down with greater effort to be made for bringing down the concentration of O3 (Zhao et al. 2021; Yu et al. 2019). Outdoor PM2.5 levels went down by 30% from 2010 to 2019 due to proper implementation of the policies. According to the Global Wind Report (2021) China is the World's leader in wind energy and hydropower generation capacity according to the 2020 Hydropower Status Report, showing its inclination towards renewable energy resources. Industrial and residential sectors switched from coal to gas, and an overall reduction in emissions was observed (State of Global Air 2020). The percentage of coal burning in total energy consumption dropped to less than 5% (A Review of 20 Years' air Pollution control in Beijing, 2019). In the light of the recent economic slowdown faced due to COVID-19, the new coal-burning capacity (Stanway 2021) instills fear of halting the progress made in curbing pollution. India: The Northern Plains of India is one region where it observes very dense fog every year during the winter months. Though topography and meteorological factors play an essential role in its formation, the contribution of air pollution cannot be ignored. Due to this reason, Delhi is the most polluted capital globally, according to the World Air Quality Report of 2020 by IQ Air (Swiss Organization). Therefore, EPCA (Environmental Pollution (Prevention and Control) Authority) was formed to manage all related environmental issues and for enforcement of GRAP (Graded Response Action Plan) formulated in 2016, whose work was to address severe air pollution emergencies in Delhi and National Capital Region. Recently, in 2020 the “Commission for Air Quality Management” (CAQM) was set up for Delhi and NCR dissolving the EPCA. This new body comprises national and state ministries, stakeholder representatives from the involved states, and people from scientific communities and civil societies (Clearing the Air: Highlights of city Actions in 2020 to Reduce Air Pollution 2020). For improving air quality, the government has taken many measures both at the national and local levels. At the national level Ministry of Environment, Forestry and Climate Change (MoEFCC) for monitoring India's policies related to the environment, forest, and climate change and CPCB (Central Pollution Control Board) is responsible for supervising all pollution-related matters and at the state level SPCB (State Pollution Control Board) takes on the same responsibility at the state level. National Ambient Air Quality Standards (NAAQS) given by CPCB have set standards for SO2, NO2, PM2.5, PM10, O3, Pb, CO, NH3, C6H6, BaP, As, and Ni emissions in industrial, residential, and rural areas; and in ecologically sensitive areas (https://cpcb.nic.in/uploads/National_Ambient_Air_Quality_Standards.pdf) Under the supervision of CPCB, NAMP (National Air Quality Monitoring Programme) oversees the trends and status of air pollutants—SO2, NOx and particulate matter (PM10 and PM2.5) and the standards are given by National Ambient Air Quality standards (enacted 1994, amended 2009). For continuous monitoring of air quality, there are 793 stations located nationwide as of July 2020 (Raw & Processed Data to Support Energy, Emission & Air Pollution Analysis in India). Another pilot project named SAFAR (System of Air Quality and Weather Forecasting and Research) provides near real-time data and a 1–3 day forecast of PM10, PM2.5, NO2, CO, and O3 for Delhi, Pune, Mumbai, and Ahmedabad (Beig et al. 2015, 2020). A report published by Sharma and Dikshit (2016) on the Air pollution of Delhi identified some sources (eateries still using coal; economically vulnerable population burning solid fuel for cooking and warming during winters; unmonitored burning of municipal solid waste; vehicles; industries; construction sites and road dust) responsible for poor air, and they suggested that tackling the problem by just managing one or two of the source alone and only during the winter months when the problem is visible will not be enough, the problem has to be treated as a whole. In the report, they have advised some measures, the government and policymakers have taken up the recommendation to some extent. Like coal-fired tandoors are banned (https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/delhi/delhi-corporations-act-against-500-eateries-withtandoors/articleshow/71845177.cms); and “Mandatory Implementation of Dust Mitigation Measures for All Construction and Demolition Activities” (Rule 106 &107) were amended in the “The Environment (Protection) Amendment Rules, 2018 to manage dust from the construction and demolition sites. Stubble burning in North Western states of the nation is amongst the prime contributor of aerosol (Beig et al. 2020; Grover and Chaudhry 2019; Sawlani et al. 2019; Singh et al. 2018; Singh 2018), which gets accumulated in the National capital of Delhi where it mixes with fog forming dense smog. Crop residue burning is now banned under Section 144 of the Civil Procedure Code (CPC) (Bhuvaneshwari et al. 2019) in Rajasthan, Uttar Pradesh, Haryana, and Punjab. The national government recently instructed the NTPC (National Thermal Power Corporation) to incorporate crop residue in power plants (Bhuvaneshwari et al. 2019). Since 2015 CPCB has made it compulsory for all industries to install OCEMS (Online Continuous Emission Monitoring Systems) to monitor pollution release from high pollution potential industries. In 2019, intending to improve ambient air quality by 2024, the government launched the National Clean Air Programme, 2019 (NCAP) for 122 cities. Its aims were very much in compliance with the sectors (transport, industry, waste burning, residential, construction, and dust) specified by UNEP. Other measures include programs such as (1) Pradhan Mantri Ujjwala Yojana launched in May 2016 aimed provide LPG to rural areas: for urban areas to replace LPG with PNG and electricity (Patnaik et al. 2018); (2) for vehicle emission and fuel quality standards are to follow BS-VI from 2020; (3) Voluntary Vehicle Fleet Modernisation program and Vehicle Scrappage policy to be introduced in 2021 for removal of old and unfit vehicles from roads; and (4) NEMMP (National Electricity Mobility Mission Plan) 2020 to push the sale of electric and hybrid cars (National Clean Air Programme 2019). Though the program lacked the legal mandate and was majorly focused on cities, it caused the local governing bodies to increase their engagement in improving air quality (State of Global Air 2020). Waste management strategy in City Action Plans is supervised by Municipal Solid Waste (MSW) Management Rules, 2016, which includes converting waste into energy, recycling, and proper management of landfill sites to avoid open burning as a form of waste disposal. A significant number of the waste to energy conversion plants remained underutilized (Cleaning the Air: A review of 10 city plans to fight Air pollution in India 2020). India's renewable energy capacity as of 30th November 2020 was 90.39 GW. To accelerate this progress, targeting increasing this capacity to 450 GW by 2030 and the government is framing its policies to increase its renewable energy market (The Hindu Business Line 2020). This will greatly help in reducing our energy dependency on non-renewable resources. Though India has been able to reduce indoor pollution largely by shifting from traditional biomass burning to the use of clean fuel (State of Global Air 2020) but it has yet to show any significant decline in the outdoor emission rates. The economic slowdown because of COVID-19 had one remarkable positive effect on the air quality worldwide. The air pollution rates in many countries around the world were significantly lowered during the lockdowns that were happening in the last two years (Javed et al. 2021). However, as both air pollution and the coronavirus affects the respiratory system, the need for improving the air quality increases many folds.
All these plans and measures are made to mitigate air pollution directly or indirectly, and thus influencing smog.

sec.title: Human health
sec.p: Inhaling fog devoid of large percentages of chemical pollutants or particulate matter is nothing more than inhaling water droplets. However, since the industrial revolution, the concentration of air pollutants have increased so has its repercussions, as most of the suspended particulate matter and pollutants can directly act as cloud condensation nuclei (CCN) or can transform into chemical compounds or free radicals that can wreak havoc on our health (Allaby 2014). Those same air pollutants can have varied effects depending on the nature of air it is suspended in (wet and foggy or dry) (Park et al. 2015). Hence the previous pieces of literature provide us with information on indirect influence or the influence of associated variables on our well-being. It has been reported that fog or misty nights have seen an increase in the number of emergency room visits for children who have asthma which is a direct indication of worsening health conditions in asthmatic children, still the study was unable to find whether it was the result of inhaling fog or the meteorological status (Kashiwabara et al. 2002). A study carried out by Avol et al. (1988) studied the short-term respiratory effects of sulfuric acid in fog on 44 adult volunteers (asthmatic and normal). By exposing the volunteers to light fog (having varied concentrations of sulfuric acid) in a controlled environment of a chamber. The results showed moderate development in respiratory symptoms and an increasing concentration of acid and even at the highest concentration of sulfuric acid, a minor influence on pulmonary function was observed. The conclusion was drawn that only modest respiratory systems and negligible pulmonary dysfunction are presumably to happen when inhaling sulfuric acid fog. Honma et al. (2000) investigated the response of asthma patients in foggy and non- foggy periods in context to effects of acid fog on inflammation and pulmonary functions; it was concluded from the study that the deterioration in the function of the respiratory system in asthma patients was caused due to inflammation induced by inhalation of naturally occurring acid fog, however, no such developments were observed in normal subjects. Another investigation done by Lavorini et al. (2001) found fog inhalation to induce cough in subjects with no asthma. It was able to evoke bronchoconstriction along with regular cough in subjects with asthma. N-nitrosodimethylamine (NDMA) of considerable concentration, found in radiation fog and clouds, was found to be a potentially carcinogenic compound (Hutchings et al. 2010).

Fog, when it morphs into smog, has detrimental impacts on human health. Since the first extensive episode of London Smog, the topic of smog and the role of aerosols and their effects on various other systems has been extensively studied. Exposure to smog can have both immediate and long-term effects on the respiratory and cardiovascular systems, causing ischemic heart disease and cerebrovascular diseases (Polivka 2018; Cai and Wang 2017). Some studies show how the smog of 1952 affected the subjects who, during the episode, were still in their mother's womb or were in their first year after being born (Bharadwaj et al. 2016; Turner 2012; Barker 1990). Bharadwaj et al. (2016) first attempted to study the health consequences of exposure to smog, taking asthma as the targeted disease. It developed later in life in that part of the population in their early life stage. In the recent past, there have been instances when fog episodes were accompanied by haze holding suspended metals (Agarwal et al. 2017) such as Na, Mg, Al, K, Ca, V, Cr, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, Zn, As, Sr, Mo, Cd, Ti, Ba, Pb and when their combined risks as a carcinogen were evaluated on children was 1.32 × 10–6 and on adults was 5.29 × 10–6 both of which were above the precautionary level of 10–6 (Li 2017). With the numerous amount of information available on the effects of ambient air pollutants (NO2, O3, PM10, and PM2.5) present in smog it is now a well established fact that increases the risk of developing cardiovascular diseases, ischemic heart disease (IHD) and various other respiratory issues (State of Global air 2019; Cai and Wang 2017; Park et al. 2015). The current pandemic situation can aggravate the health risks associated with smog, as both targets the respiratory system. The elderly and the people already suffering from any other type of cardiovascular or respiratory disease are at higher risk from smog, similarly the coronavirus disease is more fatal to them. The synergistic effect of COVID-19 and smog is explained in detail by Javed et al. (2021) in their review.

Much research was performed on the influence of air pollution on the pulmonary and cardiovascular systems. Research surrounding cognitive abilities and psychological effects started appearing over the past two decades. Children exposed to the heavily polluted air of Mexico city have higher chances of developing Neuroinflammation; this was concluded from their MRI (Magnetic Resonance Imaging) scan; another thing that was found was that these kids performance was comparatively poor to the children from cleaner air group in memory; cognition and intelligence test (Calderón-Garcidueñas et al. 2008). Inflammation in the brain interrupts the blood–brain barrier putting the children and new adults at a higher risk of developing diseases related to the central nervous system (such as Parkinson's and Alzheimer's disease), auditory language impairment, poor cognitive and memory (Calderón-Garcidueñas et al. 2012). Prenatal exposure to high concentrations of PAH, which is precursor gas for the development of photochemical smog (Polycyclic Aromatic Hydrocarbons), can impact a child's learning and understanding abilities in addition to the development of anxiety and depression (Genkinger et al. 2015; Perera et al.2012). Cognitive abilities in both older men and women have also been reported to compromise long-term exposure to particulate matter (Weuve et al. 2012; Power et al. 2011). In Barcelona, it was concluded by Vert et al. (2017) that adults are likely to develop depression when exposed for an extended time to particulate matter and nitrogen oxides. A thorough review linking air pollutants with brain function is provided by Power et al. (2016), and a short review is provided by Underwood (2017).

Tian et al. (2008) reported the influence of fog on malaria incidence in a rainforest area of China. The study was performed by Ecological time series analysis from the fog and malaria data. The positive impact of fog frequency on malaria incidences was observed after a gap of seven months, which may have resulted from additional water input for the breeding grounds of mosquitoes.

With the increasing air pollution across the globe, there is a vast sea of research dedicated to the influence of almost all air individual pollutant species but have mostly been restricted to lungs and heart diseases; there is a lack of research on the synergistic effect of various chemical species present in fog droplets, with regards to other diseases and its influence on other parts of the body. Proper pathogenesis on how a person already affected by a particular disease responds to inhalation of polluted fog for short and long exposure for various regions, as different locations can have different fog characteristics. In terms of neurological and psychological implications of smog, a large portion of the research is still concentrated in the developed nations; there is a dire need to conduct such research in developing nations as well where the cities are frequently inundated in smog, as the likes of Indian and Chinese cities.

sec.title: Transportation and economy
sec.p: Visibility reduction due to fog is a danger to any type of transportation activity, whether land, sea, or aviation (Croft 2003). Land transportation, including both roadways and railways, is prone to delays and disruption. Accidents on roads due to collisions are frequently observed in places under the influence of dense fog. Although accidents occur primarily due to collisions, some of them may be attributed to fire during a collision. Around the world, accidents related to fog result from restricted navigation ability caused due to restricted visibility and also because of the driver's inability to gauge the speed limits and the safe distance between the vehicles during such weather conditions. Fatal accidents due to poor visibility can also lead to a chain of collisions resulting in a piled-up condition (Whiffen et al. 2004). In India alone, reported road accidents due to fog in the year 2017 was 26,982 killing 11,090 and injuring 24,828; in 2018 the number increased to 28,029, killing 11,841 and injuring 25,265 (Road Accidents in India 2018), in 2019 the numbers further increased to 33,602 killing 13,405 and injuring 30,776. The road accidents in 2019 increased by 19.9%, and the reported fatalities increased by 13.2%, which was reported to be the highest in accidents caused due to poor weather conditions (Road Accidents in India 2019). Peng et al. (2018) analyzed the effect of reduced visibility on traffic flow parameters (speed, volume, and headway) on different vehicles (passenger cars and trucks) and vehicles running on different lanes implementing the statistical approach of t-test and ANOVA. Through the study, it was concluded that the headway variance could be a significant cause of accidents; effect on passenger cars is comparatively notable than trucks; different lanes experience different effects, and the effects on traffic parameters are more prominent in the inner lane and also when visibility < 300 m. It has been previously reported that fatal crashes in low visibility conditions due to fog or smoke are relatively more severe and may involve multiple vehicles for the Florida region (Abdel-Aty et al. 2011).

The cancellation, delays, and diversion of flights caused due to fog create inconvenience for the passengers, flight crew, and transportation management (The Economic Times 2019). The hassle of making alternate arrangements may sometimes add extra costs. Trade and commerce, businesses, import and export of goods and services are expansively dependent on transportation and are hindered, affecting the economy. Some studies reported that economic loss due to restrained transportation is comparable to tornadoes, hurricanes, and winter storms (Gultepe et al. 2007, 2009). Weather hazards, including mountain wave turbulence, clear air turbulence (CAT), microbursts, thunderstorm, poor visibility, and wind shear, are among the primary contributing reasons for aircraft and helicopter mishaps (Jenamani and Kumar 2013). Low visibility can hamper aircraft navigation safety in the course of takeoff, landing, and taxiing. It was reported that in Canada, one-half of all-weather-associated casualties at the airport was because of low visibility (Leung et al. 2020). Specifically, in the US, accidents during take-off and crashes after takeoff are more frequent when visibility < 0.3 km (Wong et al. 2006). Pilots have expressed their concern regarding low visibility, stating that they could lose their spatial awareness and taxi to the wrong region (Obradovich et al. 1998). To avoid any chance of collision with fuel trucks, other aircraft, personnel, and other vehicles in the ramp area, pilots had to reduce their taxing speed by one-half to one-third of the typical speed for fear of their inability to see in foggy weather (Andre 1995). As a precautionary measure, the distance separation between arriving and departing aircraft is more significant than usual, leading to delays and cancellation of flights. In addition, these foggy conditions often act as reasons that can lead to delays in emergency response, search and rescue endeavors (Joe et al. 2020; Croft 2003). Diverted, delayed, and cancelled domestic and international flights in the Indira Gandhi International (IGI) Airport accounted for an approximate loss of 3.9 million USD (248 million Indian rupees) for 2011–2016, during the winter months when the dense fog conditions are prevalent (Kulkarni et al. 2019). A prior study conducted by Jenmani and Kumar, 2013 showed that the second-highest number (approximately 16%) of aircraft accidents between the period of 1992 to 2008 were attributed to low visibility; similar situations were observed in the US.

sec.title: Ecology
sec.p: The conditions of increased relative humidity, decreased evapotranspiration, more significant diffuse radiation, and trapped carbon dioxide in the inversion layer all prevail in foggy conditions, enhance photosynthesis, and augment plants’ productivity and growth (Zhang et al. 2015a, b). Fog plays the role of both vector and medium in various ecosystems around the globe, inclusive of the coastal, desert, alpine, and inland ecosystems transporting and controlling input of crucial limiting resources such as light, moisture, and nutrients. Processes of decomposition, productivity, and water fluxes in a given ecosystem are affected by fog as it is a crucial component in mechanisms of crown wetting, elemental decomposition, light scattering, and absorption (Tognetti 2015; Weathers et al. 2020).

Fog is seen as a source of water in a local ecosystem, where the precipitation levels are incapable of fulfilling water requirements for both flora (Emery 2016; Jacobson et al. 2015) and fauna (Nørgaard and Dacke 2010; Parker and Lawrence 2001). The desert ecosystem is one such example where the vegetation is majorly dependent on fog for its moisture (Kalivodová et al. 2020; Lvončík et al. 2020; Riccardi et al. 2020; Lehnert et al. 2018) and nutrient (González et al. 2011) requirements. Hamilton and Seely (1976) performed the most remarkable research that paved the way for studying the dependency of desert species on fog water; Seely and Hamilton (1976), reporting the fog basking physiology of tenebrionid beetle (Onymacris unguicularis, Lepidochora discoidalis, L. porti, and L. kahani). A minimum of 48 animal species of the Namib Desert has been reported to consume fog water either in the liquid or vapor phase (Mitchell et al. 2020). Water-limited ecosystems have vegetation that has characteristic features making them adaptable to such harsh weather conditions here; the fog water is intercepted by the leaves (Riccardi et al. 2020; Borthagaray et al. 2010). Dwarf succulents species of Canophytumand Lithops are dependent on fog water for their survival in the desert. Guo et al. (2017) showed that there would be a reduced number of fog days in the future, habitat loss, and range contraction for the two species. The first attempt to study the influence of fog on vegetation implementing satellite data considering two sites of Namib Desert relieved a positive impact on the vegetation in their study areas (Qiao et al. 2020). In the Atacama desert, Sotomayor and Drezner (2019) investigated the alteration in the microclimate caused by the dominant plant species in the fog desert. The extreme weather conditions are regulated by fog itself; any amelioration by the plants was also restricted on foggy days. Warren-Rhodes et al. (2013) conducted a study to observe the role of light, rain and fog on hypolithic communities of Namib Desert; in the study, it was found that the physical ecology of the community benefited from the presence of fog, the community was thriving, an adequate supply of water in the form of fog helped the microorganism to colonize readily on smaller sized rocks. Except for the Namib Desert, there is a lack of research in other desert systems exploring the dependency of desert animal species on fog (Mitchell et al. 2020). Coastal ecosystems dependent on fog for their sustenance will be affected mainly by any notable shift in fog; locations that experience dry summers, e.g., Mediterranean regions (Ferraguti et al. 2013; Pignatti et al. 2006), South Africa East Asia (Pignatti et al. 2006; Hukusima et al. 2005), Chile, Mexico (Pignatti et al. 2006) and California, are more likely to face habitat loss riparian, intertidal, and terrestrial species. Some researches on the implications of fog on the vegetation found in the California region have been investigated (Fischer et al. 2009; Ingraham and Matthews 1995). Winter chill provided by the foggy conditions of lowered minimum solar radiation lowered maximum and mean temperatures create an appropriate environment for fruit and nut productivity in California (Baldocchi and Waller 2014). During the summer drought, the plant species of the coastal prairie grassland utilized fog water rather than the remaining water from the last rainfall; the difference in utilization pattern was also observed for different species giving advantage to fog water using species over those which cannot (Corbin et al. 2005). In California, Santa Cruz regions, elevated levels of monomethyl mercury (MMHg) are found in fog water samples (Weiss-Penzias et al. 2012, Weiss-Penzias et al. 2016). This heavy metal is a neurotoxin and tends to bioaccumulate in the food web (Ortiz et al. 2015). Due to wet deposition of MMHg, higher mercury concentration was found in Puma (Puma concolor), where the concentration of Hg was more in adults than the younger ones. Hg entered the food chain via Lichens, where Puma consumed the mule deer, and Lichens were a significant portion of food for the deer species; this led to Hg’s bioaccumulation with the progression of each level of the food chain (Weiss-Penzias et al. 2019).

Chances of forest fire may also increase due to reduced relative humidity and rise in temperatures since these conditions may prevail due to a decline in fog and cloud cover (Torregrosa et al. 2014). In forests, droplets of fog drip down from trees, leaves, and stems to the surface soil moisture (Li et al. 2018; Poca et al. 2018). Dependence of the Redwood forest ecosystem on fog was investigated by Dawson (1998), in his study he found that though the fog input was normal, but the dependence on fog was more during the summer months, later studies concluded that fog promoting water conservation alongside reducing the probability of water scarcity (Johnstone and Dawson 2010). Low clouds provide an atmospheric mechanism for redwood water conservation by reducing transpiration rates during the dry summer season. The most likely effect of fog decline is heightened drought sensitivity for coastally restricted plants. Fog is a dominant climatic factor on the California coast, and long-term reductions likely have and may continue to impact the water and carbon economy of redwoods and other coastal endemic species. Interaction of nutrients that are brought to soil or plant by fog (González et al. 2011) is a less investigated topic; however, some studies have shown fog being a source of nitrogen for redwood trees (Templer et al. 2015), of phosphorus in the dry tropical forest of Mexico (Vandecar et al. 2015). Carbone et al. (2013) studied the response of the Bishop Pine ecosystem to low stratus clouds and fog drip on the microbial and plant activity, and it was found that the vegetation in areas having consistent cloud cover faced less water stress; increased basal growth; increased sap velocity and increased contribution in the carbon cycle by microbes. Baguskas et al. (2016) found that a single fog event of more significant magnitude was capable of counterbalancing the effects of seasonal drought on the California pine forest where the young sapling trees were more susceptible to changes in moisture content in the soil, the water status of Bishop pine saplings was more dependent on fog water than there mature counterparts. The presence of patches of rainforest found in the semi-arid climate of Chile is supported by the marine fog prevalent in the region; the windward side of the forest had maximum regeneration, whereas the leeward side had maximum mortality proving the significance of fog water in the region (del Val et al. 2006). There are many regions around the world, especially the tropical and subtropical regions where the presence of fog is a characteristic feature of the cloud forest, water loss due to transpiration in such forest type is primarily kept in check because of the wet and cold environment provided by fog (Regalado and Ritter 2021; Kalivodová et al. 2020; Goldsmith et al. 2013; Ritter et al. 2009) as well acting as a subsidiary water source (Berry et al. 2014). Mexican weeping pine species (Alvarado-Barrientos et al. 2014) of the montane forest also showed similar observations (Gotsch et al. 2014). A form of fog known as the acid fog has been observed to harm Beech (Nara et al. 2001), hindering physiological activity and growth of its seedlings (Shigihara et al. 2008), Red Spruce (Jagels et al. 2002, 1989). Red spruce on exposure to the acid fog of pH 4.2 initially showed an increase in wax production, but on long-term exposure, a decrease was observed; reduced de nova wax synthesis rate; altered wax composition causing a decline in secondary alcohol production (pH 3.0 fog). Wettability and thickness of cuticular membrane of red spruce were affected (Percy et al. 1990, 1992). Another research conducted by Igawa et al. (2002) observed calcium and boron leaching happening in the shrinking fir forest present in the acid fog prevalent area; similar results were observed in simulated conditions making the trees calcium and boron deficient, which might have been a cause of declining forest cover.

Singh and Giri (2011), in their study, observed increased yield of wheat crop in relation to increased fog and mist duration in Amritsar, the cause behind this was reduced surface temperature, which was the resultant of radiative cooling caused by the restricted solar influx. Crop production in South West China benefits from fog since it cuts the high-intensity solar radiation during the morning hours, thus tempering the photodamage inflicted by chilling (Zhang et al. 2014).

sec.title: Fog as a resource
sec.p: q = rate of water collected (L h−1), w = water content of the air (g m−3), A = cross-sectional area of the mesh (m2), η = fog collection efficiency due to fog (unitless), V = wind speed (m s−1), 3.6 = conversion factor to express q in terms of L h−1.

Fw = fog water yield (L), fc = fog collector efficiency based on the material of mesh (unitless), FPI = fog potential index (unitless), f(H) = function of relative humidity (unitless), f(W) = function of wind speed (unitless), A = area of fog collector mesh (m2).

The potential of fog water collection is distinct to the site, depending on meteorological parameters and the design of the harvesting system. Meteorology cannot be controlled; therefore, it becomes more crucial for good design to maximize the collecting capabilities. The quality of collected water is affected by air quality and particles that get stuck on the collecting mesh. Fog has been known to dissolve bicarbonates, calcium, sodium chloride (Klemm et al. 2012), heavy metal such as mercury (Ritchie et al. 2006), nitrates, organic carbon, and other ions (Raja et al. 2008) depending upon the concentration of the dissolved chemical species may affect the quality of collected water accordingly.

Fog water is currently utilized for drinking and domestic purposes, but for irrigation purposes, reports indicating its usage are less; however, there is scope to be used for reforestation (Domen et al. 2014). The semi-arid region of southwest Morocco is a coastal region barely receiving rainfall with depleted aquifers; however, the site is covered with fog half the year and now uses this fog as a freshwater source (Dodson and Bargach 2015). Survival rates and health of saplings are aided by water. Valencia region of Spain utilized fog water to restore forest after a wildfire, and the experiment was successfully reviving the pine forest. A similar practice was conducted near the desert regions of Peru by Ramírez et al. (2012) for irrigation of 2 years old Myrcianthes ferreyrae trees.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: The review’s objective was to provide an overview of various aspects of fog, including its controlling factors, its formation; its type; techniques for its detection and prediction; its implication on-air, humans, ecology, and transport. In many places, fog is generally viewed as a local phenomenon, and in many cases, it is. It expands up to hundreds of kilometers in many places, e.g., the Northern Plains of India. The factors that influence its formation, evolution, and dissipation are for sure controlled by local factors such as wind speed and temperature; characteristics of surface and air mass; physical and chemical properties of Condensation nuclei; stability of boundary layer; vertical and horizontal wind flow; cloud cover; relative humidity and terrain. However, large-scale wind circulation cannot be ignored, as they can very much control the local meteorological conditions that require more exploration for its incorporation in the prediction models. Efforts need to be made in the direction of the direct role of soil properties on fog. There are so many aspects of fog, and each forms a separate area of research. To understand various aspects of fog, research has been conducted widely and profoundly, but the researchers have repeatedly stated that fog forecasting is still lacking. There are many techniques through the fog that can be predicted or observed; apart from the NWP models, other techniques are rapidly developed, especially artificial intelligence. Identification of commonalities between various research studies provides insight into the fog life cycle. It thus helps in selection and development techniques for better prediction, which is possible with extensive research. Understanding the factors influencing and the physical processes involved in fog formation, evolution and dissipation help improve the prediction capabilities of the current techniques available and develop new algorithms in forecasting. Simulation of fog alongside improving the prediction also helps in understanding the involved mechanisms. Improved prediction and detection will significantly contribute to curtailing the accidents and economic losses related to fog. On the other hand, it will help identify locations where fog water can be economically collected.

Before and during the initial years of the past century, the fog was viewed as nothing more than an obstruction in visibility creating nuisance in transportation and, however, with the increased use of coal after the industrial revolution; the term smog was coined and popularized, drawing attention on its direct detrimental impact on humans. Previously the microphysical properties were studied only from the angle of increasing the prediction capabilities of the prediction models; however, after the emergence of smog, concern was paid from the perspective of its health impacts. The urban atmosphere is saturated with various chemicals and CCN; their interactions among themselves and other metrological components need more comprehensive work on various regions as the behavior may vary with each location. Because of the complexity of atmospheric processes, the cause-and-effect relationship is not always consistent. Prior studies have shown that during the initial stages of haze fog events, the concentration of particulate matter increases, resulting from physical and chemical processes such as forming secondary particles and chain reactions all happening together. In addition to this, fog also has scavenging properties, so the particulate matter concentration drops after the fog event is over. These occurrences depict the importance of identifying and quantifying short-lived intermediate species formed during secondary aerosol generation. To garner such information, interdisciplinary techniques should be incorporated in the forecasting models to elucidate molecular-level processes. The characteristics, distribution, and evolution of CCN must be better understood to be adequately incorporated into the prediction models. Much exploration is required to understand fog concerning bioaerosols and their influence on human health (Gao et al. 2015). In the section of 'fog formation and classification,’ as discussed, turbulence can have two contradictory effects on fog; therefore efforts are needed to determine threshold values of turbulent intensity, as there may be chances of this value range varying with other characteristics of different fog types.

It is predicted that the cities will become more concentrated throughout the twenty-first century (Kii 2021), this will impact the entire energy and infrastructure sector, but this can also lead to a rise in per capita pollution that can, in turn, influence the health of all those people unless the government and scientist effectively upgrade their strategies. One of the many lessons that the current global pandemic situation has taught us is that the government must be prepared enough to tackle the various problems before becoming uncontrollable.

Atmospheric conditions required for fog formation are also suitable for restricting the dispersal of air pollutants. Its ample supply in the locality provides a more significant number of condensation surfaces for fog droplet formation. India's air quality is worse during winters and requires effective policies to mitigate it. For regulating emissions from industries, policy suggestions were given by Harvard Kennedy School and University of Chicago researchers in “A Roadmap Towards Cleaning India’s Air” (https://epic.uchicago.in/wp-content/uploads/2018/08/POLICY-BRIEF-A-ROADMAP-TOWARDS-CLEANING-INDIAS-AIR-1-1.pdf). More recommendations for improving the air quality of India were given by Ganguly et al. (2020) and Bhuvaneshwari et al. (2019). Some of the strategies suggested in “Cleaning the Air: A review of 10 city plans to fight Air pollution in India” are (1) strengthening of regulatory frameworks, (2) strengthening of legal enforcement, and vehicle operation and access restrictions. The Supreme Court of India in 2018 has directed the Delhi government to come up with a real-time monitoring emission monitoring system on the road, incorporating remote sensing machines for easy detection of vehicles whose emissions are relatively high, to send notice to the vehicle owners regarding the same (https://www.ndtv.com/delhi-news/supreme-court-directs-delhi-government-to-buy-remote-sensing-machines-to-detect-pollution-1850508). As stated earlier, the problem of heavy aerosol loading from burning of crop residues can be managed by implementing the strategies devised by Dutta et al. (2020) including conservation of residue into biomass or briquettes; rotation of crops which is not limited to rice and wheat; practicing conservative farming; and use of crop residue directly for energy production in state-level thermal power plants; and conversion of residue into ethanol. The major cause of fog formation in the Indo-Gangetic Plains is the weather itself not much can be done in this regard, however, its conversion to smog can be controlled to some extent if the above-mentioned actions are taken and monitored properly. Though the measures suggest keeping Delhi in mind, pointers can be taken and used for other locations in the world.

Considering all aspects of fog, the information gathered from the prior research studies can be implemented to better evaluate and improve existing prediction and forecasting systems and framing policies.
